abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Type specimens have high scientific importance because they provide the only certain connection between the application of a Linnean name and a physical specimen. Many other individuals may have been identified as a particular species, but their linkage to the taxon concept is inferential. Because type specimens are often more than a century old and have experienced conditions unfavourable for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> preservation, success in sequence recovery has been uncertain. This study addresses this challenge by employing next‐generation sequencing (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NGS</jats:styled-content>) to recover sequences for the barcode region of the cytochrome <jats:italic>c</jats:italic> oxidase 1 gene from small amounts of template <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> quality was first screened in more than 1800 century‐old type specimens of Lepidoptera by attempting to recover 164‐bp and 94‐bp reads via Sanger sequencing. This analysis permitted the assignment of each specimen to one of three <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> quality categories – high (164‐bp sequence), medium (94‐bp sequence) or low (no sequence). Ten specimens from each category were subsequently analysed via a <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PCR</jats:styled-content>‐based <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NGS</jats:styled-content> protocol requiring very little template <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>. It recovered sequence information from all specimens with average read lengths ranging from 458 bp to 610 bp for the three <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> categories. By sequencing ten specimens in each <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NGS</jats:styled-content> run, costs were similar to Sanger analysis. Future increases in the number of specimens processed in each run promise substantial reductions in cost, making it possible to anticipate a future where barcode sequences are available from most type specimens.</jats:p>
title: <scp>DNA</scp> barcodes from century‐old type specimens using next‐generation sequencing
